cluster_classes.class_description: Macroscopic structural parts of plants, such as leaves and stems, that provide surfaces or support for chrysalis attachment during butterfly metamorphosis.
cluster_classes.class_group: Biological Structures and Substances in Butterfly Metamorphosis
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: The caterpillar attaches itself to a leaf or stem and forms a protective shell.

members.entity_description: Flat, typically green plant organ attached to a stem, which can serve as an attachment surface for a chrysalis.
Supportive plant structure that bears leaves and can serve as an attachment surface for a chrysalis.

cluster_classes.class_description: External spine- or hair-like body structures on caterpillars that provide protection against predators as part of their anti-predator adaptations.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Some caterpillars have spines or hairs for protection

members.entity_description: Spine-like structures on some caterpillars that serve a protective function.
Hair-like structures on some caterpillars that provide protection.

cluster_classes.class_description: Camouflage adaptations in caterpillars, such as twig or leaf mimicry, that reduce detection by predators as part of their anti-predator strategies.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Some caterpillars ... mimic the appearance of twigs or leaves to camouflage themselves from predators.

members.entity_description: Caterpillar camouflage strategy where their appearance resembles twigs.
Camouflage adaptation where caterpillars resemble leaves to avoid predation.

cluster_classes.class_label: Metamorphic Body Fluids and Liquefied Tissues
cluster_classes.class_description: Biological liquids or semi-liquids involved in insect metamorphosis, including internal fluids used to expand new structures (e.g., wing fluid) and the liquefied body material formed as larval organs dissolve inside the chrysalis.
cluster_classes.class_group: Biological Structures and Substances in Butterfly Metamorphosis
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Internal fluid the butterfly pumps into its wings; organs dissolve into a soupy substance during metamorphosis.

members.entity_description: Internal fluid the butterfly pumps into its wings to expand and harden them.
Liquid-like mixture formed when the caterpillar’s organs dissolve during metamorphosis.

remarks: This class intentionally groups both pumped internal fluid (e.g., hemolymph-like wing fluid) and the liquefied tissue mixture from dissolved organs. Note that member 'soupy substance' currently has an entity_type_hint of BiologicalState, but its usage here is as a fluid substance; consider reviewing that entity_type_hint upstream.

cluster_classes.class_description: Structural anatomical components of butterfly wings, such as the paired wings that form and expand during metamorphosis.
cluster_classes.class_group: Biological Structures and Substances in Butterfly Metamorphosis
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Paired flight organs... initially emerging soft and wrinkled before fully developing for flight.

members.entity_description: Paired flight organs of the adult butterfly that form during metamorphosis, initially emerging soft and wrinkled before fully developing for flight.

cluster_classes.class_description: Physical or developmental states of butterfly wings (e.g., soft and wrinkled immediately after emergence from the chrysalis).
cluster_classes.class_group: Biological Structures and Substances in Butterfly Metamorphosis
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Paired flight organs... initially emerging soft and wrinkled before fully developing for flight.

members.entity_description: Initial physical state of a butterfly’s wings right after emerging from the chrysalis.

cluster_classes.class_description: Anatomical structures directly involved in the caterpillar-to-butterfly transformation, including larval organs that dissolve, the liquefied tissues that reorganize, the new adult tissues and appendages that form (e.g., antennae), and the protective pupal casing (chrysalis) that encloses the organism during metamorphosis.
cluster_classes.class_group: Biological Structures and Substances in Butterfly Metamorphosis
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Its organs dissolve into a soupy substance, and new tissues and structures, such as wings and antennae, begin to form.

members.entity_description: Internal bodily structures of the caterpillar that dissolve during metamorphosis inside the chrysalis.
Developing anatomical features that form from dissolved caterpillar material during metamorphosis.
Sensory appendages of the adult butterfly that form as new structures during metamorphosis.
Protective pupa casing formed by a caterpillar during the pupal stage, enclosing it as it undergoes metamorphosis into a butterfly.

splits.name: Chrysalis (Pupal Casing)
splits.description: The external pupal casing formed by a caterpillar that encloses and protects it during metamorphosis into a butterfly.

args.justification: ClsR_0bd3da69 mixes internal anatomical structures that transform during metamorphosis (organs, new tissues, antennae) with the external protective chrysalis casing, which is conceptually a distinct pupal covering; splitting out the chrysalis yields more coherent classes.

args.new_description: Internal anatomical structures directly involved in the caterpillar-to-butterfly transformation, including larval organs that dissolve and the new adult tissues and appendages (e.g., antennae) that form from the reorganized material inside the chrysalis.
args.new_class_group: Biological Structures and Substances in Butterfly Metamorphosis
args.justification: After moving the chrysalis to its own class, the remaining members of ClsR_0bd3da69 are exclusively internal body structures, so renaming and refining the description clarifies this narrower scope while keeping the existing class group.

args.new_description: The external pupal casing formed by a caterpillar that encloses and protects it as it undergoes metamorphosis into a butterfly.
args.new_class_group: Biological Structures and Substances in Butterfly Metamorphosis
args.justification: The new split class for the chrysalis should be explicitly labeled and attached to the same high-level group of metamorphosis-related structures to reflect its role as the external pupal casing.

executed_decisions.justification: ClsR_0bd3da69 mixes internal anatomical structures that transform during metamorphosis (organs, new tissues, antennae) with the external protective chrysalis casing, which is conceptually a distinct pupal covering; splitting out the chrysalis yields more coherent classes.

executed_decisions.new_description: Internal anatomical structures directly involved in the caterpillar-to-butterfly transformation, including larval organs that dissolve and the new adult tissues and appendages (e.g., antennae) that form from the reorganized material inside the chrysalis.
executed_decisions.new_class_group: Biological Structures and Substances in Butterfly Metamorphosis
executed_decisions.justification: After moving the chrysalis to its own class, the remaining members of ClsR_0bd3da69 are exclusively internal body structures, so renaming and refining the description clarifies this narrower scope while keeping the existing class group.

executed_decisions.new_description: The external pupal casing formed by a caterpillar that encloses and protects it as it undergoes metamorphosis into a butterfly.
executed_decisions.new_class_group: Biological Structures and Substances in Butterfly Metamorphosis
executed_decisions.justification: The new split class for the chrysalis should be explicitly labeled and attached to the same high-level group of metamorphosis-related structures to reflect its role as the external pupal casing.

cluster_classes.class_description: Butterflies as individual holometabolous insects, including generic butterflies and sex-specific adults relevant to life-cycle traits such as egg laying and metamorphosis.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: All entities concern butterflies as insects undergoing complete metamorphosis, including females and species-level differences.

members.entity_description: Insects that undergo complete metamorphosis through egg, larval, pupal, and adult stages.
Adult female butterflies that lay eggs on specific host plants, initiating the butterfly life cycle.

remarks: This class is now empty after splitting into separate generic and female-butterfly organism classes and can likely be deprecated or removed in a clean-up step.

cluster_classes.class_description: Role of the reproductive partner that butterflies seek during the adult stage for mating.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Throughout their adult stage, butterflies focus on finding a mate and reproducing to continue the life cycle.

members.entity_description: Reproductive partner that butterflies seek during the adult stage.

cluster_classes.class_description: Species-level groupings of butterflies, treated as taxonomic categories whose differing traits affect egg characteristics, metamorphosis duration, and adult lifespan.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: All entities concern butterflies as insects undergoing complete metamorphosis, including females and species-level differences.

members.entity_description: Different kinds of butterflies (species-level categories) whose distinct traits influence egg characteristics, metamorphosis duration, and adult lifespan.

splits.name: Butterflies (individual organisms, general)
splits.description: Butterflies as individual holometabolous insects, without specifying sex, undergoing complete metamorphosis through egg, larval, pupal, and adult stages.

splits.name: Female butterflies (adult females)
splits.description: Adult female butterflies that lay eggs on specific host plants, initiating the butterfly life cycle.

args.justification: The original class mixes generic butterflies with the specific subset of adult female butterflies, which are conceptually distinct organism categories and should be modeled as separate classes.
args.remark: After this split, the original class becomes an empty container and can likely be deprecated or cleaned up in a later pass.

args.new_description: Individual butterflies as holometabolous insects, without specifying sex, undergoing complete metamorphosis through egg, larval, pupal, and adult stages.
args.justification: Set a precise label/description for the newly split generic-butterfly class and align it to a unified butterfly-focused Class_Group that covers organisms, taxa, and roles.

args.new_description: Adult female butterflies responsible for egg laying, representing the sex-specific subset of butterfly organisms relevant to reproduction and life cycle traits.
args.justification: Clarify that this class is specifically for adult female butterflies and align it to the same butterfly biology Class_Group as related organism and taxon classes.

args.new_description: Species-level taxonomic categories of butterflies whose differing traits affect egg characteristics, metamorphosis duration, and adult lifespan.
args.justification: Keep this as the species-level taxon class but harmonize its Class_Group with the organism classes to reflect a coherent butterfly biology and life cycle domain.

args.new_description: The reproductive partner role that butterflies seek during the adult stage for mating, specifically in the context of butterfly life cycles.
args.justification: Maintain this as a role class but align its Class_Group with butterfly organisms and taxa so that all butterfly-related biology and life cycle concepts are connected.

args.new_name: Butterflies (legacy, split into specific organism classes)
args.new_description: Legacy container class that previously mixed generic butterflies and female butterflies; its members have been split into more precise organism classes.
args.remark: This class is now empty after splitting into separate generic and female-butterfly organism classes and can likely be deprecated or removed in a clean-up step.
args.justification: Document the result of the split and align the legacy class to the same Class_Group while flagging it for potential deprecation.

executed_decisions.justification: The original class mixes generic butterflies with the specific subset of adult female butterflies, which are conceptually distinct organism categories and should be modeled as separate classes.
executed_decisions.remark: After this split, the original class becomes an empty container and can likely be deprecated or cleaned up in a later pass.

executed_decisions.new_description: Individual butterflies as holometabolous insects, without specifying sex, undergoing complete metamorphosis through egg, larval, pupal, and adult stages.
executed_decisions.justification: Set a precise label/description for the newly split generic-butterfly class and align it to a unified butterfly-focused Class_Group that covers organisms, taxa, and roles.

executed_decisions.new_description: Adult female butterflies responsible for egg laying, representing the sex-specific subset of butterfly organisms relevant to reproduction and life cycle traits.
executed_decisions.justification: Clarify that this class is specifically for adult female butterflies and align it to the same butterfly biology Class_Group as related organism and taxon classes.

executed_decisions.new_description: Species-level taxonomic categories of butterflies whose differing traits affect egg characteristics, metamorphosis duration, and adult lifespan.
executed_decisions.justification: Keep this as the species-level taxon class but harmonize its Class_Group with the organism classes to reflect a coherent butterfly biology and life cycle domain.

executed_decisions.new_description: The reproductive partner role that butterflies seek during the adult stage for mating, specifically in the context of butterfly life cycles.
executed_decisions.justification: Maintain this as a role class but align its Class_Group with butterfly organisms and taxa so that all butterfly-related biology and life cycle concepts are connected.

executed_decisions.new_name: Butterflies (legacy, split into specific organism classes)
executed_decisions.new_description: Legacy container class that previously mixed generic butterflies and female butterflies; its members have been split into more precise organism classes.
executed_decisions.remark: This class is now empty after splitting into separate generic and female-butterfly organism classes and can likely be deprecated or removed in a clean-up step.
executed_decisions.justification: Document the result of the split and align the legacy class to the same Class_Group while flagging it for potential deprecation.

cluster_classes.class_description: Deprecated historical container that previously mixed butterfly nectar (food source) and proboscis (mouthpart); kept only for backward compatibility and should not receive new members.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Adult butterflies feed on nectar from flowers using their long, tubular mouthparts called proboscis.
remarks: This class was refactored into separate nectar and proboscis classes and now serves only as a historical/deprecated container; consider removal in a future cleanup step.
This class is empty and explicitly deprecated; label and type hint tightened so it is clearly non-usable going forward while preserving it for legacy references.

cluster_classes.class_description: Deprecated umbrella class for butterfly wing anatomy. This class has been superseded by more specific subclasses: 'Butterfly Wing Structures' and 'Butterfly Wing Physical States'. No new entities should be assigned here.
cluster_classes.class_group: Biological Structures and Substances in Butterfly Metamorphosis
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Paired flight organs... initially emerging soft and wrinkled before fully developing for flight.
remarks: This class has been split into more specific subclasses: 'Butterfly Wing Structures' and 'Butterfly Wing Physical States'. It should no longer receive new entities.
Formally marking this as a deprecated umbrella class prevents future entities from being mis-assigned here instead of the more precise wing structure/state classes.

cluster_classes.class_description: Umbrella class referring generally to reproductive roles and processes in the adult butterfly stage.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Throughout their adult stage, butterflies focus on finding a mate and reproducing to continue the life cycle.
remarks: Original member entities have been split into separate role and process subclasses; this parent class can be used as a more abstract reproduction concept if needed.

cluster_classes.class_description: Nectar as the primary liquid food resource consumed by adult butterflies, typically obtained from flowers.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Adult butterflies feed on nectar from flowers using their long, tubular mouthparts called proboscis.

members.entity_description: Sugary liquid produced by flowers that serves as food for adult butterflies.

cluster_classes.class_description: The long, tubular proboscis mouthpart of adult butterflies used to drink nectar from flowers.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Adult butterflies feed on nectar from flowers using their long, tubular mouthparts called proboscis.

members.entity_description: Long, tubular mouthpart of adult butterflies used to drink nectar from flowers.

args.new_description: Deprecated umbrella class for butterfly wing anatomy. This class has been superseded by more specific subclasses: 'Butterfly Wing Structures' and 'Butterfly Wing Physical States'. No new entities should be assigned here.
args.justification: Current class_group ('Biological Structures and Substances in Butterfly Metamorphosis') is overly broad and misleading for a class that specifically targets wing anatomy; update to a precise wing-anatomy group while keeping it clearly deprecated.

executed_decisions.new_description: Deprecated umbrella class for butterfly wing anatomy. This class has been superseded by more specific subclasses: 'Butterfly Wing Structures' and 'Butterfly Wing Physical States'. No new entities should be assigned here.
executed_decisions.justification: Current class_group ('Biological Structures and Substances in Butterfly Metamorphosis') is overly broad and misleading for a class that specifically targets wing anatomy; update to a precise wing-anatomy group while keeping it clearly deprecated.

cluster_classes.class_description: Broad ecological systems and the overall natural environment within which butterflies and their life cycles occur, including ecosystems and the wider natural world.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: generic ecological community context … overall ecological and biological environment

members.entity_description: Interacting community of organisms and their physical environment in which caterpillars and butterflies act as pollinators and prey.
The broader ecosystem and biological processes that butterfly life cycles are part of.

cluster_classes.class_description: System-level ecological states and outcomes, such as biodiversity and balanced plant populations, that are influenced by butterflies and their interactions.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: maintaining the balance of plant populations … contributing to overall biodiversity

members.entity_description: Ecological state where plant species abundance is maintained within an ecosystem.
Variety of living organisms in an ecosystem to which butterflies contribute.

cluster_classes.class_label: Butterfly Egg-Laying Sites and Larval Food Leaves
cluster_classes.class_description: Leaf surfaces and plant leaves used by butterflies as oviposition sites and as primary food sources for emerging larvae, emphasizing the microhabitat function of leaf undersides and host foliage.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Eggs are laid on the underside of leaves to protect them from predators; caterpillars feed on leaves.

members.entity_description: Protected surface on the bottom of plant leaves where butterfly eggs are usually laid.
Plant leaves that provide surfaces for butterfly egg laying and serve as a primary food source for caterpillars.

cluster_classes.class_description: Organisms and trophic roles involving butterflies and their life stages, including predators of adults, caterpillars, and eggs, host plants as food sources and oviposition sites, and butterflies as prey within the food web.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: food source for birds, reptiles, and other insects

members.entity_description: Vertebrate animals that can prey on butterflies as a food source.
Cold-blooded vertebrates that may consume butterflies as part of their diet.
Non-butterfly insects that use butterflies as prey within the ecosystem food web.
Specific plant species used by butterflies as oviposition sites and as food sources for emerging larvae.
Role of butterflies as prey providing nourishment to birds, reptiles, and other insects.
Animals that prey upon caterpillars, driving their need for camouflage and protection.
Organisms that might consume or harm butterfly eggs, prompting eggs to be laid on leaf undersides.

splits.name: Butterfly Host Plants as Oviposition and Larval Food Resources
splits.description: Plant species that serve specifically as host plants for butterflies, providing oviposition sites and primary food resources for larvae within the butterfly life cycle.

args.justification: The original 'Butterfly Trophic Interactions' class mixes conceptually different roles—animal predators of butterflies vs. plant host resources; host plants are structurally distinct and deserve their own class focusing on oviposition and larval feeding resources.

args.new_description: Animals and trophic roles in which butterflies (at egg, larval, and adult stages) function as prey, including birds, reptiles, and other insects, and the role of butterflies as a food source within the food web.
args.new_class_group: Butterfly Ecology, Habitat, and Food Web
args.justification: After moving host plants to a dedicated class, the remaining members of ClsR_456c8b15 are all predators and the prey role of butterflies, so the class should be renamed and re-described to reflect this narrower, cleaner scope and aligned under a refined ecology/food web group.

args.new_name: Butterfly Host Plants and Larval Resources
args.new_description: Host plant species used by butterflies for egg laying and as primary food resources for caterpillars, emphasizing their role in the butterfly life cycle and food web.
args.new_class_group: Butterfly Ecology, Habitat, and Food Web
args.justification: The new split class should be clearly labeled and grouped to highlight host plants as a distinct ecological resource within the butterfly habitat and food web context.

args.new_class_group: Butterfly Ecology, Habitat, and Food Web
args.justification: This class describes broad ecosystems and the natural environment for butterflies, which fits best under a unified higher-level group that explicitly covers ecology, habitat, and food web structure.

args.new_class_group: Butterfly Ecology, Habitat, and Food Web
args.justification: This class captures ecological outcomes (biodiversity, plant population balance) driven by butterflies, which are tightly linked to ecological context and trophic interactions and should share the same broader ecology/habitat/food web group.

args.new_class_group: Butterfly Ecology, Habitat, and Food Web
args.justification: This class focuses on egg-laying sites and larval food leaves, which are specific habitat features embedded in the same ecological and food web context as the other classes and should share the unified Class_Group.

executed_decisions.justification: The original 'Butterfly Trophic Interactions' class mixes conceptually different roles—animal predators of butterflies vs. plant host resources; host plants are structurally distinct and deserve their own class focusing on oviposition and larval feeding resources.

executed_decisions.new_description: Animals and trophic roles in which butterflies (at egg, larval, and adult stages) function as prey, including birds, reptiles, and other insects, and the role of butterflies as a food source within the food web.
executed_decisions.new_class_group: Butterfly Ecology, Habitat, and Food Web
executed_decisions.justification: After moving host plants to a dedicated class, the remaining members of ClsR_456c8b15 are all predators and the prey role of butterflies, so the class should be renamed and re-described to reflect this narrower, cleaner scope and aligned under a refined ecology/food web group.

executed_decisions.new_name: Butterfly Host Plants and Larval Resources
executed_decisions.new_description: Host plant species used by butterflies for egg laying and as primary food resources for caterpillars, emphasizing their role in the butterfly life cycle and food web.
executed_decisions.new_class_group: Butterfly Ecology, Habitat, and Food Web
executed_decisions.justification: The new split class should be clearly labeled and grouped to highlight host plants as a distinct ecological resource within the butterfly habitat and food web context.

executed_decisions.new_class_group: Butterfly Ecology, Habitat, and Food Web
executed_decisions.justification: This class describes broad ecosystems and the natural environment for butterflies, which fits best under a unified higher-level group that explicitly covers ecology, habitat, and food web structure.

executed_decisions.new_class_group: Butterfly Ecology, Habitat, and Food Web
executed_decisions.justification: This class captures ecological outcomes (biodiversity, plant population balance) driven by butterflies, which are tightly linked to ecological context and trophic interactions and should share the same broader ecology/habitat/food web group.

executed_decisions.new_class_group: Butterfly Ecology, Habitat, and Food Web
executed_decisions.justification: This class focuses on egg-laying sites and larval food leaves, which are specific habitat features embedded in the same ecological and food web context as the other classes and should share the unified Class_Group.

cluster_classes.class_description: Processes and structures involved in the sexual reproduction of flowering plants, including pollination, flowers, pollen, and the plants that bear them.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Butterflies transfer pollen between flowers during pollination, helping plants reproduce via flowers, nectar, and pollen.

members.entity_description: Biological process in which pollen is transferred between flowers, often by organisms, enabling plant reproduction and helping maintain plant populations.
Reproductive structures of plants that produce nectar and pollen visited by butterflies.
Plant reproductive grains carried by butterflies between flowers during pollination.
Organisms that produce flowers, nectar, and pollen and depend on pollination to reproduce.

cluster_classes.class_description: Biological process where butterflies produce offspring to continue their species' life cycle.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Throughout their adult stage, butterflies focus on finding a mate and reproducing to continue the life cycle.

members.entity_description: Biological process where butterflies produce offspring to continue their species’ life cycle.

splits.name: Pollination in flowering plants
splits.description: The biological process in which pollen is transferred between flowers (often by animals) to enable sexual reproduction in flowering plants.

args.justification: ClsR_1e9d0076 currently mixes a reproductive process (pollination) with reproductive structures and organisms; splitting out the process yields clearer process vs structure classes.

args.new_name: Flowering plant reproductive structures and organisms
args.new_description: Structures and organisms involved in the sexual reproduction of flowering plants, including flowers, pollen, and the flowering plants that bear them.
args.justification: After splitting out the pollination process, the remaining members in ClsR_1e9d0076 are all structures/organisms; renaming and aligning the class_group to a shared biological reproduction domain makes its scope explicit and connects it to related reproduction classes.

args.new_description: Pollination as a reproductive process in flowering plants, in which pollen is transferred between flowers by wind, animals, or other vectors, enabling fertilization and seed production.
args.justification: The new split class cleanly represents the reproductive process aspect; giving it a precise label and the same biological reproduction class_group as other reproduction-focused classes improves schema coherence.

ClsR_2a20cb5a describes butterfly reproduction, a biological reproduction process; aligning its class_group with the plant reproduction process group creates a unified higher-level group for animal and plant reproduction processes.

executed_decisions.justification: ClsR_1e9d0076 currently mixes a reproductive process (pollination) with reproductive structures and organisms; splitting out the process yields clearer process vs structure classes.

executed_decisions.new_name: Flowering plant reproductive structures and organisms
executed_decisions.new_description: Structures and organisms involved in the sexual reproduction of flowering plants, including flowers, pollen, and the flowering plants that bear them.
executed_decisions.justification: After splitting out the pollination process, the remaining members in ClsR_1e9d0076 are all structures/organisms; renaming and aligning the class_group to a shared biological reproduction domain makes its scope explicit and connects it to related reproduction classes.

executed_decisions.new_description: Pollination as a reproductive process in flowering plants, in which pollen is transferred between flowers by wind, animals, or other vectors, enabling fertilization and seed production.
executed_decisions.justification: The new split class cleanly represents the reproductive process aspect; giving it a precise label and the same biological reproduction class_group as other reproduction-focused classes improves schema coherence.

ClsR_2a20cb5a describes butterfly reproduction, a biological reproduction process; aligning its class_group with the plant reproduction process group creates a unified higher-level group for animal and plant reproduction processes.

cluster_classes.class_description: Biological processes in butterfly development, specifically molting (repeated skin shedding as the caterpillar grows) and metamorphosis (transformation into a butterfly inside the chrysalis).
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: molting as repeated skin shedding; metamorphosis as transformation into a butterfly

members.entity_description: Biological process where caterpillars shed their skin multiple times as they grow.
Transformation process where a caterpillar changes into a butterfly inside the chrysalis.

cluster_classes.class_description: Time-related attributes that quantify or describe how long butterfly metamorphosis inside the chrysalis takes (e.g., number of days or weeks).
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: metamorphosis inside the chrysalis and its duration from days to weeks

members.entity_description: Time span of metamorphosis inside the chrysalis, ranging from days to weeks depending on species.

splits.name: Butterfly Molting Process
splits.description: Biological process where caterpillars shed their skin multiple times as they grow.

splits.name: Butterfly Metamorphosis Process
splits.description: Biological process where a caterpillar transforms into a butterfly inside the chrysalis.

args.justification: The original class bundles two distinct biological processes (molting and metamorphosis) that are conceptually separate stages of the butterfly life cycle and should be modeled as separate process classes for cleaner schema and better alignment with the metamorphosis duration attribute class.
Assign the same lifecycle-focused Class_Group to the new Butterfly Molting Process class to keep it connected with related development and metamorphosis concepts.
Assign the lifecycle-focused Class_Group to the new Butterfly Metamorphosis Process class so it is clearly linked to the metamorphosis duration attribute class and other developmental processes.

args.new_description: Time-related attributes that quantify or describe how long butterfly metamorphosis (inside the chrysalis) takes, such as its duration in days or weeks for different species.
args.justification: Clarify in the description that this class specifically captures time attributes of the metamorphosis process, aligning it more explicitly with the new Butterfly Metamorphosis Process class while keeping the same Class_Group.

executed_decisions.justification: The original class bundles two distinct biological processes (molting and metamorphosis) that are conceptually separate stages of the butterfly life cycle and should be modeled as separate process classes for cleaner schema and better alignment with the metamorphosis duration attribute class.
Assign the same lifecycle-focused Class_Group to the new Butterfly Molting Process class to keep it connected with related development and metamorphosis concepts.
Assign the lifecycle-focused Class_Group to the new Butterfly Metamorphosis Process class so it is clearly linked to the metamorphosis duration attribute class and other developmental processes.

executed_decisions.new_description: Time-related attributes that quantify or describe how long butterfly metamorphosis (inside the chrysalis) takes, such as its duration in days or weeks for different species.
executed_decisions.justification: Clarify in the description that this class specifically captures time attributes of the metamorphosis process, aligning it more explicitly with the new Butterfly Metamorphosis Process class while keeping the same Class_Group.

cluster_classes.class_label: Butterfly immature life stages (larva and pupa)
cluster_classes.class_description: Developmental life stages of butterflies before adulthood, specifically the feeding larval (caterpillar) stage and the pupal stage during which metamorphosis occurs.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Both entities are defined as developmental life stages within the butterfly life cycle.

members.entity_description: The larval life stage of a butterfly, immediately after the egg hatches, during which the organism is a caterpillar that feeds and grows on host plants before forming a pupa.
The third developmental life stage of a butterfly, in which the organism is enclosed in a chrysalis and undergoes metamorphosis from larva to adult.

remarks: Currently models two distinct immature stages (larva and pupa) in a single class; this is acceptable as a grouped immature-stage concept, but if finer granularity is later required, this class could be split into separate larval and pupal life-stage classes.

cluster_classes.class_description: The initial life stage of butterflies, during which the organism exists as an egg laid on suitable host plants.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: The initial life stage of a butterfly, during which the organism exists as an egg laid by a female butterfly on suitable host plants.

members.entity_description: The initial life stage of a butterfly, during which the organism exists as an egg laid by a female butterfly on suitable host plants.

cluster_classes.class_description: The distinct developmental stages in a butterfly's life cycle (egg, larva, pupa, adult), treated as a collection of life stages.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: the complete developmental process of butterflies from egg to adult, namely egg, larva, pupa, and adult

members.entity_name: stages of the butterfly's life cycle
members.entity_description: The distinct developmental phases a butterfly passes through from egg to adult.

remarks: This class intentionally represents the collection of all stages rather than a single stage; keep it distinct from the individual life-stage classes but within the same Butterfly Life Cycle Stages group.

args.new_description: The immature developmental stages of a butterfly after hatching and before adulthood, including the feeding larval (caterpillar) stage and the pupal (chrysalis) stage during which metamorphosis to the adult occurs.
args.remark: Currently models two distinct immature stages (larva and pupa) in a single class; this is acceptable as a grouped immature-stage concept, but if finer granularity is later required, this class could be split into separate larval and pupal life-stage classes.
args.justification: Harmonizes this class with the other butterfly life-stage classes by standardizing the Class_Group label and class_type_hint and clarifying that it covers both larval and pupal stages as immature stages within the same life-cycle domain.
Aligns the egg-stage class with the other butterfly life-stage classes by using a consistent, domain-level Class_Group label and class_type_hint focused on biological life stages.

args.new_description: The complete set of developmental stages in a butterfly's life cycle (egg, larva, pupa, adult), treated as a collection of related life stages.
args.remark: This class intentionally represents the collection of all stages rather than a single stage; keep it distinct from the individual life-stage classes but within the same Butterfly Life Cycle Stages group.
args.justification: Clarifies that this class is a collection covering all stages and standardizes its Class_Group with the individual butterfly life-stage classes for coherent schema connectivity.

executed_decisions.new_description: The immature developmental stages of a butterfly after hatching and before adulthood, including the feeding larval (caterpillar) stage and the pupal (chrysalis) stage during which metamorphosis to the adult occurs.
executed_decisions.remark: Currently models two distinct immature stages (larva and pupa) in a single class; this is acceptable as a grouped immature-stage concept, but if finer granularity is later required, this class could be split into separate larval and pupal life-stage classes.
executed_decisions.justification: Harmonizes this class with the other butterfly life-stage classes by standardizing the Class_Group label and class_type_hint and clarifying that it covers both larval and pupal stages as immature stages within the same life-cycle domain.
Aligns the egg-stage class with the other butterfly life-stage classes by using a consistent, domain-level Class_Group label and class_type_hint focused on biological life stages.

executed_decisions.new_description: The complete set of developmental stages in a butterfly's life cycle (egg, larva, pupa, adult), treated as a collection of related life stages.
executed_decisions.remark: This class intentionally represents the collection of all stages rather than a single stage; keep it distinct from the individual life-stage classes but within the same Butterfly Life Cycle Stages group.
executed_decisions.justification: Clarifies that this class is a collection covering all stages and standardizes its Class_Group with the individual butterfly life-stage classes for coherent schema connectivity.

cluster_classes.class_description: The final, winged life stage of a butterfly following the pupa (chrysalis), during which the organism is fully developed, capable of flight, feeding, mating, and reproduction.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: The fourth and final stage of the butterfly's life cycle is the adult stage... ready to take flight for the first time.

members.entity_description: Butterfly immediately after exiting the chrysalis, with soft, wrinkled wings.
The final, winged life stage of a butterfly following the pupa (chrysalis), during which the organism is fully developed, capable of flight, feeding, mating, and reproduction.
Adult stage that the caterpillar develops into after metamorphosis.

cluster_classes.class_description: Properties and qualitative states associated with the adult butterfly life stage, such as flight capability, lifespan duration, and aesthetic qualities.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: The fourth and final stage of the butterfly's life cycle is the adult stage... ready to take flight for the first time.

members.entity_description: Butterfly’s ability to fly once its wings are fully developed.
Duration of life of butterflies in the adult stage, typically days to weeks.
The state of the butterfly as a fully developed, aesthetically admired adult in flight.

cluster_classes.class_description: The complete developmental process of a butterfly from egg through larva and pupa to the adult stage.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: from egg through larva and pupa to adult … butterfly fluttering by … moment of beauty and grace

members.entity_description: The full developmental path of a butterfly from egg through larva and pupa to adult.
The complete biological process a butterfly passes through from egg, through larva and pupa, to the adult stage.
